awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Analyses of polymorphism and divergence to illuminate molecular evolution permissive of zoonoses in SARS and COVID-19
awd_abstract_narration:
COVID-19 disease has caused the third major outbreak in the past two decades resulting from a spillover of an animal coronavirus to humans. Among them, it is by far the most severe. Novel diseases typically appear because of such spillovers. However, it is unknown what genetic changes in the virus causing COVID-19 enabled it to infect humans. To identify those genetic changes, this project will use newly developed computational methods to compare the genes in coronaviruses infecting humans to the genes in coronaviruses infecting other animal hosts. This comparison of viral genomes will provide insight into which sites within coronavirus genomes enable the switching of host species as well as which sites change following host switches. Awareness of these genetic mechanisms is critical to determining if general rules underlie the ability of coronaviruses to switch hosts, as well as to provide necessary historical context for the changes coronavirus genomes have experienced following the onset of human infections. The ensuing knowledge provides precise guidance on new targets for ongoing decisions regarding vaccine design and drug development. Results of this project will also be incorporated into multiple engaging and educational exhibits at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. 

This project will apply molecular evolutionary approaches to reveal the rates of evolution of SARS-CoV-1, SARS-CoV-2, and of viruses sequenced from reservoir hosts, revealing the strength of selection across sites occurring proximate to zoonosis within the viral genomes. First, phylogenetic comparisons of extant SARS-causing, SARS-like, and COVID-19-causing viral sequences collected from infected humans and from animal reservoirs will be used to reconstruct the history of coronavirus evolution. Second, the rate of change of each nucleotide within each gene—and each amino acid site within each protein—in viruses that were transmitting within the animal reservoir, in viruses transmitted among humans during the SARS outbreak, and in viruses transmitted among humans during the COVID-19 pandemic will quantified. Third, virus gene sequences that bracketed (pre- and post-) the host transition events for both SARS and COVID-19 will be estimated through phylogenetic ancestral state reconstruction methods. Finally, application of a novel computational approach comparing the divergence between reconstructed ancestors to the polymorphism present during the outbreak will identify genomic sites under selection that are associated with host transitions. This divergence will be mapped to known protein domains and structures, illuminating sites important to human infection and transmission, and thereby aiding molecularly targeted vaccine and therapy development. This RAPID award is made by the Systematics and Biodiversity Science Cluster in the Division of Environmental Biology, using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Yale University - School of Public Health

por.por_cntn:
One direct publication from this study is in press in the top medical journal The Lancet Microbe (Townsend JP, Hassler HB, Wang Z, Miura S, Singh J, Kumar S, Ruddle NH, Galvani AP, and Dornburg A. 2021. The durability of immunity against reinfection by SARS-CoV-2: a comparative evolutionary study). An additional manuscript titled, ?Coronavirus evolution illuminates seasonality of COVID-19? by Townsend JP, Lamb AD, Hassler HB, Sah P, Alvarez Nishio A, Nguyen C, Galvani AP, and Dornburg A. is submitted, and another on ?Purifying selection spanning the zoonosis of SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2? by Townsend JP, Gaughran S, Hassler HB, Fisk JN, Nagib M, Wu Y, Singh J, Wang Y, Wang Z, Galvani AP, and Dornburg A is in prep.


 

  Scientific training and public education: The project provided training in genome data analysis, evolutionary biology, and virus pandemics for an international visiting scholar, and one PhD student, two masters degree graduates and two undergraduates (Aia Alvarez Nishio and Jaiveer Singh) at Yale. For public education, this project enabled the development of a new exhibit in partnership with the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences (NCMNS), an admission-free museum that is visited by more than 1.4 million people each year. We continue to work the NCMNS to develop a series of interactive virtual reality (VR) experiences that provide an overview of the spread of COVID-19 and current research on the SARS-CoV-2 virus in a VR gaming environment. This exhibit is providing training for a Ph.D. student at the University of North Carolina Charlotte, Haris Muharemovic, who has taken the lead in game development and will utilize tracking of user experiences to study the efficacy of approaches to learning in a VR environment. Once deployed, this exhibit can dispel popular misconceptions surrounding the outbreak as well as the science surrounding immunology and evolutionary biology in the United States, thereby promoting a more informed citizenry. We have additionally given virtual talks through several interacting partner institutions on the science of SARS-CoV-2. We have disseminated scientific results within the academic community via 

  1. via personal outreach to the scientific community, in which our research helped created general knowledge that guided three publications: 1) Wells CR, et al., 2021. Optimal COVID-19 quarantine and testing strategies. Nature Communication; 2) Wells CR. et al, 2020. Impact of international travel and border control measures on the global spread of the novel 2019 coronavirus outbreak. PNAS 117 (13) 7504?7509; 3) Moghadas SM et al, 2020. Projecting hospital utilization during the COVID-19 outbreaks in the United States. PNAS 117 (16) 9122-9126. Additional manuscripts by collaborators and colleagues whose basis was synergistic to this work are submitted for review or near completion. 

  2. Research talks for the scientific community, including a research webinar for the NSF-funded COVID Information Commons (https://covidinfocommons.datascience.columbia.edu/events/june-2021-covid-19-research-webinar-lightning-talks-and-qa), a poster presentation by a graduate student on the durability of immunity to COVID-19 at the 2021 virtual meeting for the Society of Molecular Biology and Evolution (https://virtual.oxfordabstracts.com/#/event/public/2080/session/24926), and an oral presentation by PI Townsend at the meetings of the International Society for Evolutionary Medicine and Public Health (https://airtable.com/shrjiil8XOjrgUSGe/tbldG4CI3RlANohd4).

We have also taken several opportunities to provide virtual outreach to the public regarding COVID-19 biology and public health:

  1. in partnership with the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences (NCMNS) including a virtual science caf? hosted by the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences on the Science of Pandemics that is publicly available on YouTube  (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lRqnRlG7OSI&t=708s), 

  2. a virtual seminar on the durability of immunity to COVID-19 for the Triangle Center for Evolutionary Medicine (TriCem; https://isemph.org/event-4483026), and

  3. a presentation by PI Townsend aimed at a K?12 audience on ?Family, school, the world, and COVID-19? for students at a local elementary school that was highly praised by the district superintendent.

 

  Public service and public health policy impacts: The Lancet Microbe study characterized the typical waning profile for IgG antibody levels to the Spike protein, Nucleocapsid protein, and to whole viral lysate and the corresponding probabilities of SARS-CoV-2 reinfection that provide a time frame crucial to numerous aspects of public health decision-making. These findings are consistent with the mounting reports of eventual reinfection by SARS-CoV-2, and indicate that reinfection after natural recovery from COVID-19 will become increasingly common as the pandemic progresses. Such results are of policy-determinative value during this critical stage of the pandemic, especially when the vaccination rate is low and COVID-19 mutants potentially become more contagious and harmful.​​


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2021
Modified by: Jeffrey P Townsend
